description:
Arthrobacter sedimenti is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Arthrobacter. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium.

Arthrobacter sedimenti was first isolated from sediment samples collected from a freshwater lake in China. The cells of this species are typically coccoid or rod-shaped, and they exhibit a characteristic cell division pattern, where the cells form V-shaped arrangements during cell division.

Phylogenetically, Arthrobacter sedimenti is closely related to other Arthrobacter species, and it is classified within the phylum Actinobacteria. The bacterium is capable of growing at a wide range of temperatures, from 4°C to 37°C, and it can tolerate moderate levels of salt (up to 5% NaCl).

Arthrobacter sedimenti is known to possess the ability to degrade various organic compounds, including aromatic compounds and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). This metabolic versatility, along with its ability to survive in diverse environmental conditions, suggests that Arthrobacter sedimenti may play a role in the cycling of nutrients and the remediation of contaminated environments.
